Dear Thomas, 

Thank you for submitting Robert Frost Helps Me Talk to My Father to Bartleby Snopes. We appreciate the chance to read your work. Unfortunately, this piece is not for us. We tend to prefer stories with more dramatic tension and more fully developed characters. This is more of anecdote. It needs more substance to carry the narrative, such as more demonstrated tension and conflict between the father and son and clarification about their relationship. 

Good luck with this one elsewhere. Feel free to try us again in the future with something new, but please wait at least one month before submitting again. 

Sincerely, 
The Editors 
Bartleby Snopes 
www.bartlebysnopes.com

You can go here to view the submission:
http://bartlebysnopes.submittable.com/user/submissions/3860190
Email: redrose108@comcast.net
First published pieces were published here

From Michelle Wittle:

Dear Poet:
ￊ
I am writing today on behalf of Rosemary Cappello, Editor of Philadelphia Poets, to ask you to submit your poems for possible publication in Philadelphia Poets Volume 20 due out in Spring 2014. Rosemary was very impressed with your work when she met you back in October at the speed dating round at Push to Publish and would like to give you the first opportunity to possibly have your work published in the Spring 2014 issue. The volumes do fill up fast, so please do not wait too long to send your work.
ￊ
Submissions will open up June, 2013. Please see the submission guidelines attached to this email. If you have any further questions, please feel free to email Rosemary or myself. We are happy to help.
ￊ
Best wishes to you,
ￊ
MM Wittle
ￊ
ￊￊ

-- 
MM Wittle, Assistant Editor, Philadelphia Poets
http://www.facebook/MMWittle

Paper only:
	ﾥ	Typed, double-spaced, on one of 8.5ￓ x 11ￓ paper
	ﾥ	Include cover letter (one page limit): name, address, phone number, email address, title of piece, and approximate word count
	ﾥ	8,000 word limit for general submissions
	ﾥ	Do not send disks or electronic files
	ﾥ	Multiple submissions not accepted from individual authors (non-contest submissions only)
	ﾥ	Simultaneous submissions require immediate notification to Fourth Genre if accepted elsewhere

Comments from Randall Brown: 

Thanks for all the kind words. My only suggestion is (perhaps) to add
something more about the process of submissions than the "numbers." For
example, those fifty pieces have been, for the most part, being written,
workshopped, revised, tweaked for usually 6 months to a year before they
are being submitted. Also, those 250 journals are all journals I have some
familiarity with‹by knowing their editor(s), their published authors,
and/or editors. So I think the Big Leagues is more than getting up to bat
more often; it is also about having better preparation, scouting, and the
like.

Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
Scribophile
Discussion for Double Word Score
Paige McKinney
Opening Comments
Nice Title! The bonus made me smile. I'll try not to spend it all in once place. ;)
Inline Critique
“C H E A T E R. Since the word is spelled out, not spoken/yelled in all caps I think it would be better if you put a period after each letter. C.H.E.A.T.E.R. Cheater. Let's see, etc. Let’s see – that’s three, four for the ‘H’, that’s seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven. Double letter for the ‘R’, that’s thirteen. And double word score. That’s twenty-six.”
“A S S H O L E. That’s one, two, double letter, that’s four, four for the ‘H’, double letter for the ‘O’, that’s ten, eleven, twelve. Twelve points. Write it down.”
“T W O T I M E R.”
“That’s two words.”
“Where’s it say you can’t use two words?” “Do you want me to look it up?”
Right here would be a good place to show the people having this competition/conversation. Are they an old married couple, young married, not married, but partners, or just dating? And where is this taking place? In a house, with a mouse; on a box, with a fox? “T W I T,” muttering Who is doing the muttering? , “that’s one, triple for the ‘W’, that’s twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, double word for the ‘T’. Thirty points.”
“You already used the double word for the ‘T’” “So.”
1 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
“So you can’t use it again. Cheater.”
Under her breath, “You’re the cheater, not me.”
“What did you say. ? ”
“Nothing – just play the game.”
“No. I want to know what you said.”
“I said it’s your turn.”
“I Q U I T.”
“That’s two words.”
“No, you don’t understand. I quit. Do you need me to spell it out?”
Closing Comments
Yes, I need you to spell it out. Reading straight dialogue is like overhearing a conversation in a restaurant and not being able to see the feuding couple on the other side of the partition--except when I'm reading I have to supply the tone of voice as well as imagine what the people might look like and their backstory.
Here, the woman seems passive agressive, and I'm left wondering why the guy didn't quit after the T W O T I M E R jab. Guilt? Pretending innocence?
I also wonder if this scenario is actually possible. Have you tried it? Did you consider having one of them use a blank tile for one of the letters? Maybe at the end. I. Q. U. I. Blank tile--what's that supposed to spell? I QUIT. That's two words, etc...
All my comments and suggestions are yours to take or leave with my best wishes (in a box, with a fox, in a house, with a mouse, here or there, anywhere). :)
Mary Jane
This was so clever, so funny. I couldn't see anything to critique. Besides that I'm hopeless at Scrabble.
Dan Hart
2 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
Opening Comments
Hi Thomas,
I decided against an in-line critique, as this is all dialog. Since it's all dialog, I won't comment on diction / etc.
Please remember these are only my subjective opinions, and must be taken with a heaping of salt.
Plot
Yes, the plot was believable. It didn't interest me, however. I think it can be summarized as, "Two people play scrabble and quibble."
Pacing
The pacing was great.
Description
There were no descriptions that I could tell.
Point Of View
No POV; I think this was all dialog.
Characters
The characters didn't seem real to me, because they had no defining characteristics beyond what they said. Neither voice felt unique to me, and I didn't identify or emphasize with either.
Dialog
The dialog seemed strong.
Grammar and Spelling
I didn't notice any issues.
3 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
Closing Comments
I think it's very well-written, and the dialog flows smooth, but to me it doesn't work as a story.
I understand it's impossible to incorporate all elements of a story into a work this short, however I think it needs a theme, a voice, an idea, or something unique that makes the story stick in my head. My favorite flash pieces, even those as short as a paragraph, stay with me for years.
In this story, I don't understand the point or the message. Linguistically, you play with the language well, and I enjoyed hearing words spelled out in my head, and used to further the argument.
But what was the message? What am I going to remember about this work in an hour, a day, or next week? What did you want to convey, that only you can convey?
Good luck with this. I think the writing is great, and the premise is there, but it seems to be missing something vital.
Malcom Tent
Granted this is clever,it is just a snippet of something else. In music no one goes to hear a musician just solo. They want to hear songs. Unless its Jazz,and jazz is just music for musicians who like to hear solos. The rest of us want songs and what you have given us is a very clever solo without the song. All the clever banter going back and forth without any internal monolouge from either character does two things it grabs our interest but leaves us wondering what brought on this conversation and the inevitable breakup. It would work well if you were writing this as a screenplay,mostly for an independant film. But just grabbing our interest and not backing up how all this came to be is just wrong even if you're just writing flash fiction. This is some really good banter but we know nothing about the characters. In fiction internal monolouge is very important. It is the building block for everything else. Even books that are dialouge heavy still have internal monolouge to bridge parts of the story together. By setting up such good banter, I could at least envision maybe a couple of hipsters somewhere in Brooklyn at a pizza parlor trading these words back and forth between themselves in an angry fashion like gun fire. Dialouge has always given me problems,but by itself,it can not sustain a story. This has the makings of a very good short story about a break up that was a long time coming.
Also,if youre going to use banter that goes back and forth in rapid fashion,it would have been great to use tage lines that hint at what the characters are thinking while they saying these things to eacth other. Go back and re-do this and cultivate it into the good story it's
4 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
waiting to become.
KC Jotter
*** even later edit/addition to comments ***
dang! I had a question about this and then I went back and I noticed that I was the one who messed up with the volley. I'm so sorry. I totally blew it. And I'd delete that part, except that maybe, if nothing else, there's something in my fumbling that will give you an idea how to write to people like me who have a deficit in the brain-cell department. Again, my apologies. I'll just keep my fingers crossed that anything else I said is marginally more intelligent.
***
Hello, Thomas. I love Scrabble and I've always wanted to have a game like this with someone to whom I REALLY wanted to say some hard-hitting things, but I never got to.
So, reading this was kind of a fantasy fulfillment for me.
I don't have any nitpicking to do. Your work is clean, there are no misspellings that I noticed on first read. The grammar is fine. So I'll continue with what I did find.
SHE: “C H E A T E R. Let’s see – that’s three, four for the ‘H’, that’s seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven. Double letter for the ‘R’, that’s thirteen. And double word score. That’s twenty-six.”
My comments are based on an assumption that you're not limited by word count, but that you still want this to be a flash piece. In this first passage, I'd like to see you ramp it really fast. Instead of just all of those double letter, double word points, why not go for gusto?
Make it active "C H E A T I N G" - and get all of the letters out in one time and getting that bonus, making the score astronomical when added with all of the double letter, double word.
Also, when you use that here, and continue with other related accusations couched in Scrabble tiles, when you get to the place where "Cheater" takes on two meanings, you won't have used the word itself already. It won't duplicate and the word "Cheater" will have a bigger impact.
HE: “A S S H O L E. That’s one, two, double letter, that’s four, four for the ‘H’, double letter for the ‘O’, that’s ten, eleven, twelve. Twelve points. Write it down.”
5 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
Right here, a man says this. Men don't usually call women assholes, at least not where I come from, so, for me, this isn't the best choice.
The rest of the dialogue, down to the part where you actually identify the speaker as female, works gender-wise. But this one doesn't.
SHE: “T W O T I M E R.”
HE: “That’s two words.”
SHE: “Where’s it say you can’t use two words?”
HE:“Do you want me to look it up?”
SHE: “T W I T,” muttering, “that’s one, triple for the ‘W’, that’s twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, double word for the ‘T’. Thirty points.”
SHE: “You already used the double word for the ‘T’” HE:“So.”
SHE: “So you can’t use it again. Cheater.”
*** - this is where she gets 2 hits
Under her breath, “You’re the cheater, not me.”
I highlighted the rest of this because when you use untagged dialogue, it's like a tennis game. You've got one point in here where "she" hits twice, and it comes right at the end of this section.
I went back through the highlighted bits and bold-tagged the dialogue. If you intend for her to hit twice, I don't think it works.
“No, you don’t understand. I quit. Do you need me to spell it out?”
I took out that bit because it's not necessary. It waters down your ending because it's almost like the author is over-explaining. I like that ending and you'll want it to have the maximum impact. Don't clue your audience into what you're ABOUT to say in a clever way.
Just say it in a clever way.
The last quibble I have is that he's the one who ends up saying "I quit." And that doesn't
6 of 20 2/26/12 9:21 AM
Double Word Score - Thomas Jay Rush | Scribophile, serious fe... http://www.scribophile.com/writing/printcomments.php?worki...
work for me either because if he is cheating, he's already quit. She needs to be the one to quit. It's a story. She called him on it with her first word on the board, they argued it (maybe some of those words could be "money" or "your mother (or yo mama to give dual meaning - yo mama being the serious implication that an in-law is a pain that's caused problems in the relationship and it can also come of as an FU type comment)" or "tightwad" ... you get the idea.
But once the drama has played out on the board, the cheater shouldn't be the one who says "I quit," because that doesn't make sense. Or maybe it does - but it doesn't make sense to me, given my value system because I feel that when people cheat on one another, they've already quit the relationship - everything else is just a formality. So in that regard, saying "I quit" when you've cheated is redundant - the quitting has already taken place and is no surprise.
I like your approach to the subject matter. I really would like to see you start off with a heavy accusation, then use each play of the game to support the accusation, while getting the odd jab in here and there. The follow through with the bang of the conclusion.
That's all I've got. I hope you find this helpful.
edit: additional comment - Oh, and one more thing - I glanced at some of the other critiques, and I disagree. I don't think you need the dialogue tags at all. Just watch your wording - make sure that at least some of the terminology has a male voice and some of the terminology or word choices have a female voice, and also make sure you've got the ball on an opposite side of the court every time so that everybody gets a turn and nobody speaks twice in a row.
Suzi Harris
Scrabble is one of my favorite games. I loved the rapid fire word choices. They really let me see the first player's anger at the other player and gives me a lot of clues to his character - at least in the eyes of the first player.
I assumed all the word choices were made by the female in the story. This made it a bit confusing for the I Quit to follow her telling the other player 'it's your turn'. The following 'That's two words.' smoothed out this bump but you might consider adding a response from the other player for clarity.
You might consider - 'Yes, I know' instead of 'No, you don't understand.' (just a thought)
Overall, think it is a wonderful concept and a great read. Wish you the best with this and hope some of my comments are helpful.

I like this idea. The scrabble terminology really makes it feel true, though I'd probably enjoy it more (not that I didn't enjoy it) if I was a hardcore (or at least conversant) scrabble player.
My main issue with this piece is the clarity. You've made it almost all dialogue (which is awesome, and I think you should cut the non-dialogue parts) but made it a little unclear who is speaking. I'll try to explain my example, but it's been a long week and I'm really tired. Here we go for trying...
Based on the order of speakers, the man is the one who cheated (in the relationship, I would assume) if we can trust the woman. It may just be me, but I associate "asshole" with a man's insult. That may be slightly sexist, but I can't imagine I'm the only one who feels like men use the word asshole more often than women.
Also, by the end of the piece, the man is the one who has become disgusted with the situation and "quits."
Basically, I want each character to have their own voice and thoughts. At the moment, it feels jumbled.

Opening Comments
The title drew me in for a look. I didn't get the point of it on the first read. At first I didn't get the point at all. What was the story?
A closer read showed the entire story beneath the layer of words on the surface. I like that a lot; and with so few total words. The casual reader will probably not like this story. People reading more closely will likely enjoy the story and the craftsmanship of the two layers. I wouldn't worry about the first group.
................................................................
The biggest flaw for me is that I can't believe the game. You have three 'bingos' in a row. At a high level, this can happen, but most people, with just a passing familiarity of the game, will have never seen this happen. This also means that your scoring is wrong, a technical error. These large flaws in the surface layer of the story are going to ruin the experience of real story in the underlying layer. Sure, most people barely know the rules of Scrabble and will not know or easily overlook these things, but I consider it a major problem. I do think, however, that this problem is entirely fixable and that doing so will put a lot of polish on the entire story at the same time.
................................................................
I've no problem accepting CHEATER as the first word in the story, and think that you can use the 'bingo' aspect to advantage. However, ASSHOLE and TWO-TIMER are way too convenient, way too overt. That's a big negative for me, being too direct for the real story, which deserves better and which is working so nicely below the surface. The beauty of this problem is that you've got nearly the entire dictionary to work and should be able to replace those words with subtler references to positive effect to both layers of the story.
................................................................
The lead-up to the ending could use adjustment also. It doesn't quite ring as believable.

We think the three poets we've had the pleasure of featuring all know how to make a damn good sandwich, different in their own way, but with a common attraction to every day life and its whimsy, sometimes tragedy, despair, hope. They've set out on the journey to, in the words of Raymond Carver, "endow those things--a chair, a window curtain, a fork, a stone, a woman's earring--with immense, even startling power."

We came upon one of Thomas Jay Rush's short stories in which the unlikely word "peas" (empowered by just the right punctuation) gave this startling effect. His poems deal similarly with everyday things and feelings in a language that is non-ornamental but that still (maybe because of this) direct our attention elsewhere, outside the poem, toward some mystery or other.

http://kitchenpoet.blogspot.com/2011_01_01_archive.html
